Beginner.title: Alphabet and Pronunciation Basics
Beginner.content: Learn the English alphabet, basic vowel and consonant sounds, and common spelling-sound correspondences. Focus on short vs. long vowels, common consonant pairs, and clear articulation.
examples: Alphabet: A B C D E F G ... Z
Short vs. long vowels: bit/beat, not/note, cut/cute
steps: Step 1: Memorize letter names and typical sounds.
Step 2: Practice short and long vowel contrasts.
Step 3: Drill common consonant clusters (bl-, tr-, st-).
Step 4: Record and compare your pronunciation with models.

Beginner.title: Syllables, Word Stress, and Rhythm
Beginner.content: Understand syllable division and primary stress in words. Learn how stress affects vowel quality and overall intelligibility.
examples: ta-ble (2 syllables), com-pu-ter (3 syllables)
Stress: PHOtograph, phoTOgraphy, photoGRAphic
steps: Step 1: Clap out syllables in common words.
Step 2: Identify primary stress using dictionaries.
Step 3: Practice minimal pairs with different stress patterns.
Step 4: Read aloud with a steady rhythm.

Beginner.title: Nouns and Pronouns
Beginner.content: Nouns name people, places, things, and ideas. Pronouns replace nouns to avoid repetition and agree in number and person.
examples: The teacher is kind. She explains well.
The books are on the table. They are new.
steps: Step 1: Identify common and proper nouns in sentences.
Step 2: Replace nouns with appropriate pronouns.
Step 3: Ensure pronoun-antecedent agreement.

Beginner.title: Articles and Basic Determiners
Beginner.content: Use a/an for singular, non-specific nouns; the for specific or known nouns. Learn this/that/these/those and basic quantifiers (some, any, much, many).
examples: I need a pen. The pen is blue.
This book is new. Those books are old.
steps: Step 1: Choose a/an based on sound (a dog, an apple).
Step 2: Use the for previously mentioned or specific items.
Step 3: Practice demonstratives (this/these vs. that/those).

Beginner.title: Be, Have, and Do
Beginner.content: Be, have, and do function as main and auxiliary verbs. Master their forms and basic uses in statements, negatives, and questions.
examples: I am a student. She is happy.
Do you like tea? I do not (don’t).
I have a car. Have you got a pen?
steps: Step 1: Memorize forms: am/is/are; have/has; do/does.
Step 2: Form negatives and questions correctly.
Step 3: Practice short answers (Yes, I do. No, she isn’t.).

Beginner.title: Simple Present
Beginner.content: Use the simple present for habits, routines, and general truths. Add -s/-es for third-person singular.
examples: She works every day.
Water boils at 100°C.
steps: Step 1: Conjugate regular verbs in all persons.
Step 2: Add -s/-es for he/she/it.
Step 3: Use do/does for questions and negatives.

Beginner.title: Present Continuous
Beginner.content: Use the present continuous for actions happening now or temporary situations.
examples: He is reading now.
They are staying with friends this week.
steps: Step 1: Form be + verb-ing.
Step 2: Learn spelling rules for -ing (run → running).
Step 3: Contrast with simple present for habits vs. now.

Beginner.title: Simple Past
Beginner.content: Use the simple past for completed actions in the past. Learn regular and common irregular verbs.
examples: She visited her parents yesterday.
He went to school by bus.
steps: Step 1: Add -ed for regular verbs.
Step 2: Memorize key irregular forms (go → went).
Step 3: Use did for questions and negatives.

Beginner.title: Basic Future: Will and Going To
Beginner.content: Use will for decisions, promises, and predictions; going to for plans and intentions.
examples: I’ll call you tonight.
We’re going to visit Rome next month.
steps: Step 1: Form will + base verb and be going to + base verb.
Step 2: Practice usage differences with timelines.
Step 3: Make predictions with evidence (Look at those clouds—It’s going to rain.).

Beginner.title: Adjectives and Adverbs (Basics)
Beginner.content: Adjectives describe nouns; adverbs modify verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs. Learn common -ly adverbs and adjective order.
examples: A very tall building.
She sings beautifully.
steps: Step 1: Place adjectives before nouns.
Step 2: Form adverbs with -ly when appropriate.
Step 3: Practice basic adjective order (opinion-size-age-color-noun).

Beginner.title: Countable/Uncountable Nouns and Plurals
Beginner.content: Differentiate countable vs. uncountable nouns and apply correct quantifiers and plural forms.
examples: Many apples, much water.
Information (uncountable), pieces of information.
steps: Step 1: Learn common uncountable nouns.
Step 2: Use some/any, much/many correctly.
Step 3: Form regular and irregular plurals (child → children).

Beginner.title: Prepositions of Place and Time
Beginner.content: Use in/on/at for places and times, and basic movement prepositions (to, from, into, out of).
examples: At 7 pm, on Monday, in July.
The keys are on the table.
steps: Step 1: Memorize common place/time patterns.
Step 2: Practice with visual prompts (maps, calendars).
Step 3: Contrast in/on/at in context.

Beginner.title: Coordinating Conjunctions and Simple Sentences
Beginner.content: Use and, but, or, so to connect words and independent clauses. Build clear simple sentences.
examples: I like tea and coffee.
He was tired, so he went to bed.
steps: Step 1: Write simple S-V-O sentences.
Step 2: Join ideas with coordinating conjunctions.
Step 3: Avoid run-on sentences with proper punctuation.

Beginner.title: Questions and Negation
Beginner.content: Form yes/no and wh- questions. Use auxiliaries for negatives and questions.
examples: Do you live here? Where do you live?
She does not (doesn’t) drive.
steps: Step 1: Invert auxiliary and subject for questions.
Step 2: Use do/does/did with main verbs.
Step 3: Practice wh- words (who, what, where, when, why, how).

Beginner.title: Imperatives and Requests
Beginner.content: Use imperatives for instructions and polite forms for requests.
examples: Open the window, please.
Could you help me, please?
steps: Step 1: Use base verb for imperatives.
Step 2: Add please and modal can/could for polite requests.
Step 3: Practice classroom and daily-life instructions.

Beginner.title: Punctuation and Capitalization (Basics)
Beginner.content: Use periods, commas, question marks, and capital letters for sentence starts, proper nouns, and the pronoun I.
examples: My name is Ana. I live in Madrid.
Where are you from?
steps: Step 1: Capitalize sentence starts and proper nouns.
Step 2: End sentences with correct punctuation.
Step 3: Use commas in simple lists.

Beginner.title: Spelling Rules and Common Patterns
Beginner.content: Learn basic spelling patterns: adding -s/-es, -ed, -ing, y → ies, doubling consonants.
examples: study → studies; stop → stopped; run → running
box → boxes; play → played
steps: Step 1: Apply rules for plurals and verb endings.
Step 2: Practice with word families.
Step 3: Keep a personal spelling list.

Beginner.title: Essential Vocabulary and Collocations (Everyday Life)
Beginner.content: Build core vocabulary for daily routines, food, travel, work, and common collocations.
examples: Make a decision, have breakfast, take a shower.
Buy groceries, catch a bus.
steps: Step 1: Learn words in context with phrases.
Step 2: Create themed word lists with examples.
Step 3: Review with spaced repetition.

Intermediate.title: Tense Review and Aspect
Intermediate.content: Contrast simple vs. continuous vs. perfect aspects to express time and completeness.
examples: I live here. I am living here temporarily.
I have lived here for five years.
steps: Step 1: Map timelines for common tenses.
Step 2: Practice substitution and transformation drills.
Step 3: Use context clues to choose the correct aspect.

Intermediate.title: Present Perfect Simple vs. Past Simple
Intermediate.content: Use present perfect for life experience and unfinished time; past simple for finished time.
examples: I’ve been to Japan. I went there in 2019.
She has just left. She left five minutes ago.
steps: Step 1: Identify finished vs. unfinished time markers.
Step 2: Use for/since with present perfect.
Step 3: Practice paired contrasts.

Intermediate.title: Present Perfect Continuous
Intermediate.content: Express actions that started in the past and continue or have recent results.
examples: I’ve been studying for three hours.
It has been raining, so the ground is wet.
steps: Step 1: Form have/has been + -ing.
Step 2: Contrast with present perfect simple (result vs. duration).
Step 3: Use with for/since and time expressions.

Intermediate.title: Past Continuous and Past Perfect
Intermediate.content: Use past continuous for background actions; past perfect for the earlier of two past events.
examples: I was cooking when she arrived.
She had finished before I called.
steps: Step 1: Build past timelines for sequences.
Step 2: Combine past simple, continuous, and perfect.
Step 3: Write narratives with clear sequencing.

Intermediate.title: Future Forms in Depth
Intermediate.content: Use will, going to, present continuous for plans, and future continuous/perfect for ongoing or completed future actions.
examples: I’m meeting Sara at 6.
This time next week, I’ll be traveling.
By 2030, we will have reduced costs.
steps: Step 1: Match form to function (plan, schedule, prediction, arrangement).
Step 2: Practice future continuous/perfect timelines.
Step 3: Write future schedules and forecasts.

Intermediate.title: Modals: Ability, Permission, Obligation, and Probability
Intermediate.content: Use can/could, may/might, must/have to/should for functions like ability, requests, obligation, advice, and degrees of certainty.
examples: You must wear a seatbelt.
She might be at home.
Could you open the window?
steps: Step 1: Group modals by function.
Step 2: Practice past forms and semi-modals (had to, be allowed to).
Step 3: Use adverbs to fine-tune certainty (probably, definitely).

Intermediate.title: Conditionals (Zero to Third)
Intermediate.content: Form and use zero, first, second, and third conditionals for facts, real possibilities, hypotheticals, and regrets.
examples: If you heat water, it boils. (Zero)
If it rains, I’ll stay home. (First)
If I had time, I would travel. (Second)
If I had studied, I would have passed. (Third)
steps: Step 1: Learn standard forms for each type.
Step 2: Practice real vs. hypothetical contexts.
Step 3: Combine with modals for nuance.

Intermediate.title: Passive Voice
Intermediate.content: Use the passive to focus on the action or result rather than the actor; form across common tenses.
examples: The report was written yesterday.
English is spoken worldwide.
steps: Step 1: Transform active to passive and vice versa.
Step 2: Choose by-phrases only when needed.
Step 3: Practice passive in reports and processes.

Intermediate.title: Reported Speech (Statements, Questions, Commands)
Intermediate.content: Report what others said using backshifting when appropriate and adjusting pronouns, time, and place.
examples: She said (that) she was tired.
He asked where I lived.
They told me to wait.
steps: Step 1: Learn reporting verbs and patterns.
Step 2: Practice backshifts and time changes.
Step 3: Report dialogues and interviews.

Intermediate.title: Gerunds and Infinitives
Intermediate.content: Use -ing or to-infinitive after specific verbs, adjectives, and expressions. Understand meaning differences.
examples: I enjoy reading.
I decided to leave.
I stopped smoking vs. I stopped to smoke.
steps: Step 1: Memorize common verb patterns.
Step 2: Practice sentence transformations.
Step 3: Note meaning changes with different forms.

Intermediate.title: Relative Clauses
Intermediate.content: Use defining and non-defining relative clauses with who, which, that, whose, where, when.
examples: The person who called is my boss.
Paris, which is beautiful in spring, is crowded.
steps: Step 1: Punctuate non-defining clauses with commas.
Step 2: Omit relative pronouns where allowed.
Step 3: Combine sentences using relative clauses.

Intermediate.title: Adverbial and Noun Clauses
Intermediate.content: Use adverbial clauses (because, although, if, when) and noun clauses (that, if/whether, wh- clauses) to expand ideas.
examples: I stayed home because I was sick.
I think (that) he is right.
Tell me where you live.
steps: Step 1: Identify clause functions.
Step 2: Practice subordinators in context.
Step 3: Embed noun clauses as subjects/objects.

Intermediate.title: Phrasal Verbs (Core Set)
Intermediate.content: Understand separable vs. inseparable phrasal verbs and common meanings.
examples: Turn on the light / Turn the light on.
Look after the kids.
Run into an old friend.
steps: Step 1: Learn particles and patterns.
Step 2: Record phrasal verbs in context sentences.
Step 3: Practice with dialogues and role-plays.

Intermediate.title: Word Formation and Collocations
Intermediate.content: Build vocabulary using prefixes, suffixes, and common collocations; recognize part-of-speech families.
examples: happy → happiness → unhappiness
strong coffee, heavy rain, make progress
steps: Step 1: Map word families (noun/verb/adj/adv).
Step 2: Learn productive affixes (un-, re-, -ness, -able).
Step 3: Study collocations with corpus-informed lists.

Intermediate.title: Discourse Markers and Cohesion
Intermediate.content: Use linking words for adding, contrasting, sequencing, and concluding to improve flow and clarity.
examples: Furthermore, however, therefore, in conclusion
First, next, finally
steps: Step 1: Categorize markers by function.
Step 2: Rewrite paragraphs to improve cohesion.
Step 3: Avoid overuse by varying expressions.

Intermediate.title: Paragraph Writing: Unity and Coherence
Intermediate.content: Write clear topic sentences, provide supporting details, and end with concluding sentences.
examples: Topic sentence introducing a single main idea.
Supporting details with examples and explanations.
steps: Step 1: Outline topic, support, and conclusion.
Step 2: Use transitions for coherence.
Step 3: Edit for relevance and clarity.

Intermediate.title: Functional Writing: Emails and Notes
Intermediate.content: Write polite, clear emails and notes with appropriate greetings, closings, and tone.
examples: Dear Ms. Lee, I am writing to...
Best regards, Kind regards
steps: Step 1: Choose formal vs. informal style.
Step 2: Use clear subject lines and structure.
Step 3: Proofread for brevity and correctness.

Intermediate.title: Listening and Speaking: Conversation Management
Intermediate.content: Use strategies to open, maintain, and close conversations; clarify and confirm information.
examples: Sorry, could you repeat that?
Just to confirm, you mean...?
steps: Step 1: Practice turn-taking and active listening.
Step 2: Use clarification and confirmation phrases.
Step 3: Role-play common scenarios.

Intermediate.title: Reading Strategies: Skimming, Scanning, Inference
Intermediate.content: Develop flexible reading strategies to locate information, get the gist, and infer meaning from context.
examples: Scan schedules for times and dates.
Infer word meaning from surrounding sentences.
steps: Step 1: Set a reading purpose.
Step 2: Practice time-limited skimming and scanning.
Step 3: Annotate texts and check predictions.

Intermediate.title: Pronunciation: Connected Speech and Intonation
Intermediate.content: Improve naturalness with linking, reductions (weak forms), and basic intonation patterns for questions and statements.
examples: Gonna, wanna (informal reductions)
Rising intonation for yes/no questions
steps: Step 1: Practice linking between words.
Step 2: Use weak forms for function words.
Step 3: Imitate natural intonation in dialogues.

Advanced.title: Advanced Modality and Inference
Advanced.content: Use modal verbs and perfect modals for present and past deduction, speculation, and evaluation.
examples: She must have left early.
They might be delaying the launch.
steps: Step 1: Review degrees of certainty with modals.
Step 2: Use perfect modals for past inferences.
Step 3: Embed modals in formal arguments.

Advanced.title: Complex Conditionals and Wishes
Advanced.content: Use mixed conditionals, inversions, and expressions of wishes, preferences, and regrets.
examples: If I had studied, I would be working there now.
I wish I had known.
I’d rather you didn’t smoke.
steps: Step 1: Map cause-time/result-time in mixed forms.
Step 2: Practice wish/if only with tense backshifts.
Step 3: Use inversion for emphasis (Had I known, ...).

Advanced.title: Emphasis, Clefting, and Fronting
Advanced.content: Use cleft sentences, fronting, and inversion to highlight information and manage focus.
examples: It was John who solved the problem.
Only then did we realize the error.
steps: Step 1: Identify focus and theme/rheme.
Step 2: Transform neutral sentences into emphatic forms.
Step 3: Apply in formal writing and speech.

Advanced.title: Advanced Passive Structures
Advanced.content: Use passives with reporting verbs, causatives, and get-passives to vary style and focus.
examples: The CEO is believed to be retiring.
We had the report edited.
He got promoted last year.
steps: Step 1: Practice passive + infinitive patterns.
Step 2: Use causatives (have/get something done).
Step 3: Choose passive for objectivity and flow.

Advanced.title: Reported Speech: Advanced Patterns
Advanced.content: Use a range of reporting verbs and nuanced backshifts; maintain coherence of reference and time.
examples: She admitted having made a mistake.
They suggested that we postpone the meeting.
steps: Step 1: Categorize reporting verbs by pattern.
Step 2: Preserve meaning with accurate backshifts.
Step 3: Summarize and synthesize multiple sources.

Advanced.title: Complex Noun Phrases and Nominalization
Advanced.content: Build dense academic-style noun phrases with premodifiers, postmodifiers, and nominalizations.
examples: The rapid international expansion of the company
The implementation of stricter policies
steps: Step 1: Layer modifiers logically.
Step 2: Convert clauses to noun phrases for concision.
Step 3: Balance density with readability.

Advanced.title: Cohesion and Coherence at Text Level
Advanced.content: Use referencing, substitution, ellipsis, and lexical cohesion to create unified, readable texts.
examples: This/that, the former/the latter for referencing
Avoid repetition with substitution and ellipsis
steps: Step 1: Annotate cohesion devices in model texts.
Step 2: Revise drafts to improve coherence.
Step 3: Use parallel structure for balance.

Advanced.title: Style and Register: Formal, Neutral, Informal
Advanced.content: Adapt grammar, vocabulary, and tone to audience and purpose in academic, business, and casual contexts.
examples: Commence vs. begin vs. start
I am writing to inquire vs. Just checking in
steps: Step 1: Analyze audience and purpose.
Step 2: Choose appropriate lexis and structures.
Step 3: Edit for consistency of register.

Advanced.title: Argumentation and Critical Writing
Advanced.content: Plan and write analytical and argumentative essays with clear thesis, evidence, counterarguments, and conclusions.
examples: Thesis-driven introduction
Counterargument with rebuttal
steps: Step 1: Outline claims, reasons, and evidence.
Step 2: Integrate quotations and paraphrases.
Step 3: Conclude with implications and limitations.

Advanced.title: Research Skills: Summarizing, Paraphrasing, and Citation
Advanced.content: Condense sources accurately, paraphrase without plagiarism, and cite using common styles.
examples: Concise abstracts and executive summaries
Signal phrases: According to..., X (2023) argues...
steps: Step 1: Take structured notes (key points, terms, data).
Step 2: Paraphrase with transformations and synonyms.
Step 3: Provide attributions and references.

Advanced.title: Phrasal Verbs and Idioms (Advanced)
Advanced.content: Master high-frequency phrasal verbs with multiple meanings and idiomatic expressions for nuance.
examples: Bring up, put off, work out (multiple senses)
Idioms: on the same page, hit the ground running
steps: Step 1: Learn meanings by context and metaphor.
Step 2: Record collocates and patterns.
Step 3: Practice in professional scenarios.

Advanced.title: Vocabulary: Collocations and Lexical Bundles
Advanced.content: Use discipline-specific collocations and multiword units to sound natural and precise.
examples: Bear in mind, as a result of, in terms of
Conduct research, pose a question
steps: Step 1: Build domain glossaries with examples.
Step 2: Extract bundles from model texts.
Step 3: Recycle target items across tasks.

Advanced.title: Pronunciation: Advanced Intonation and Clarity
Advanced.content: Control pitch, stress, rhythm, and reduction for clarity in presentations and discussions.
examples: Contrastive stress for emphasis
Falling vs. rising-falling contours
steps: Step 1: Mark nuclear stress in sentences.
Step 2: Practice scripts for presentations.
Step 3: Get feedback from recordings.

Advanced.title: Professional Communication and Presentations
Advanced.content: Deliver structured presentations; handle Q&A; write reports, proposals, and executive summaries.
examples: Signposting: First, I’ll outline...
Bridging questions: That’s a great question; to clarify...
steps: Step 1: Plan with audience-focused structure.
Step 2: Use visuals and signposting effectively.
Step 3: Anticipate questions and rehearse answers.

Advanced.title: Editing and Proofreading
Advanced.content: Revise for grammar, style, concision, and coherence; use checklists and tools to improve accuracy.
examples: Eliminate redundancy and wordiness.
Ensure subject–verb agreement in complex sentences.
steps: Step 1: Edit in stages (content, structure, language).
Step 2: Use style guides and consistency checks.
Step 3: Apply readability and grammar tools.

Advanced.title: Reading: Critical Analysis and Synthesis
Advanced.content: Evaluate arguments, identify bias, and synthesize multiple sources into a coherent perspective.
examples: Identify assumptions and evidence quality.
Compare and contrast authors’ positions.
steps: Step 1: Annotate claims, evidence, and warrants.
Step 2: Create comparison matrices.
Step 3: Write literature-mapped summaries.

Advanced.title: Listening: Lectures and Note-Taking
Advanced.content: Follow complex talks using signposting, chunking, and structured note-taking systems.
examples: Cornell notes with cues and summaries
Recognize signals: to begin with, moving on to...
steps: Step 1: Pre-listen by previewing key terms.
Step 2: Take notes using consistent formats.
Step 3: Review and expand notes post-listening.

Advanced.title: Literary Analysis
Advanced.content: Interpret themes, symbols, narrative perspective, and stylistic devices across genres.
examples: Analyzing Shakespeare’s imagery in Macbeth.
Exploring justice and empathy in To Kill a Mockingbird.
steps: Step 1: Close-read passages and annotate devices.
Step 2: Connect textual evidence to thematic claims.
Step 3: Write a thesis-driven analytical essay.

Advanced.title: Grammar in Academic Writing: Precision and Clarity
Advanced.content: Use parallelism, subordination, and punctuation for precise, readable academic prose.
examples: Parallel structure in lists and comparisons
Semicolons for complex coordination
steps: Step 1: Diagnose sentence-level issues.
Step 2: Apply targeted rewrites.
Step 3: Maintain consistency in tense and voice.

Advanced.title: Exam and Assessment Strategies
Advanced.content: Develop strategies for timed tasks, error correction, and performance on standardized assessments.
examples: Allocate time per section and question type.
Use elimination and inference in reading tasks.
steps: Step 1: Analyze test formats and rubrics.
Step 2: Create practice plans with feedback loops.
Step 3: Reflect on errors to prevent recurrence.
